etymologies: late 18th century: from the modern Latin genus name of the foxglove, from digitalis (herba) ‘(plant) relating to the finger’, from digitus ‘finger, toe’; suggested by German Fingerhut ‘thimble or foxglove’

definitions: a drug prepared from the dried leaves of foxglove and containing substances (notably digoxin and digitoxin) that stimulate the heart muscle.
shortDefinitions: drug prepared from dried leaves of foxgloves and containing substances notably digoxin and digitoxin that stimulate heart muscle
